Math's Fundamental Flaw. Dr. Derek Muller @ Veritasium. Not everything that is true can be proven. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HeQX2HjkcNo youtube]
The main figures in this story are Cantor, Gilbert, Gödel, Turing. Mr. Muller frames this historical journey with Conway's Game of Life.
Euclid has been the bedrock of mathematics for two thousand years until Lobashevsky and Gauss discovered non-Euclidean geometries.
Cantor introduced set theory and with it a diagonalization proof that there are more real numbers between 0 and 1 than there are integers.
Hilbert believed a formal and rigorous system of mathematical proof based on set theory could reconcile the challenges discovered over the 1800s.
There were three big questions that  Hilbert wanted answered about mathematics.
Complete. Can every true statement be proved?
Consistent. Is it free of contradictions?
Decidable. Is there an algorithm that can always determine whether a statement follows  from the axiom?

Bertrand Russel found a paradox in set theory of self-referential sets: the set, R, of all sets that do not contain themselves. If R does not contain itself, then it must be included in R. If R is contained, then it must be excluded.
Russel and Alfred North Whitehead created a formal system in Principia Mathematica after Hilbert's challenge.
Gödel's first incompleteness theorem proved mathematics is incomplete. A formal system could express a self-referential contradiction that would be both true and unprovable within the system.
Gödel published a second incompleteness theorem which proved any consistent formal system cannot prove its own consistency.

Turing envisioned a computing machine that forms the basis of all computing. With another stroke of self-reference, he proved no algorithm could determine if another program will run to completion. Mathematics is not decidable.
